If he took my advice to relax, he'd be a different person now, but to each his own.

There was this one time, I had to fight off two hulking Chimeras and these were no normal Chimeras. These had three heads man, that was insane. If you took care of two of the faces with the shotgun, there was one more left. But it was no problem for my skills you know? I kicked those cerberus bitches ass so hard they bled a river of blood. I've done a ton of those things man. I once went to Pripyat, after hearing all the stories of how fucked up it was. I had to get there, check it out myself. There was thousands of Tushkanos, 50 monolith squads at every step, for real. I took down plenty of them but I couldn't carry anymore loot, so I got back here. By the way, do you have any idea how to release the safety on this piece of shit pistol? I couldn't figure it out it's a new gun for me.

I'm sure you are eager to explore and find some shiny artifacts, but what if I tell you that the real money to be had in the Zone, are definitely not the artifacts? I'm going to tell you exactly that, and it doesn't even involve firing a gun. I know it sounds too good to be true, but that is not a good enough reason to dismiss it. What I need from you is only an initial sum of money, think of it as an investment. And get this, it's going to spit out a return, ten times what you invested. I found this guy, that knows this other guy, that sets all this up. It's all legit you could ask around, but that would just make other Stalkers wanting to cash in, and this deal might not be on the table for long if that happens. Think about it and bring in the dough when you are nice and ready.

I don't really talk to strangers, here we are all strangers. I get that and most people feel comfortable spilling their life stories to any one, but I'm not that kind of a guy. I realize that anyone who isn't shooting at you, you feel like a brother, and if you share a cup of shroom tea with a Zone man, it's as if he's your best man all of a sudden. See I never adapted to that, I've always been left to tend for myself.

Who are you living for? What is your "idea" that keeps you alive, when every single thing out in the Zone wants you dead? Imagine if there was a democratic poll where everything in the Zone could vote, so they could all vote: the missions, the anomalies, bandits, mutants, cancer, tetanus, poisoning etc). The results would always weigh in heavily, even unanimously, against you being alive. You've been elected to be dead, by the Zone. Why would you not agree with them? You know what keeps me moving and talking here? These kind of conversations. Not Vodka, not Cocaine nor those wonderful porn mags Beard distributes in return for a hefty fee, it's simple chats with simple people like you. Thank you for taking the time to have a nice chat.

They put some garbage in the imported tobacco that is sold here, it reduces the effects of radiation and helps the body recover. Some miracle shit the Ukrainian government came up with when they had to deal with the first Chernobyl explosion. So smoking one off after eating some shitty cyst infested meat from the Zone, really works wonders. Unless you want to spend the whole day puking and get cancer in a few years. We are all sterile anyway, our balls can't handle the radiation, and those that aren't sterile, have defective sperm. Imagine watching your beautiful wife give birth to a disgusting mutant, just because you spent a few months in the Zone back in when you were young? Everything has consequences, or at least that's what the doctors say.

Tag along with larger groups when you are not prepared for the horror of being alone. They won't mind unless you keep waving a shooter in their faces. That way, you get the safety of numbers, you have more fun and you might learn a thing or two from their conversations. You could also learn by watching them in action. Their tactics, how they handle weapons, how they move. It's all important and essential if you want to stay one of us "living people". If not, you could just join the zombie hoard by walking to their abode, or chilling outside while a psy emission is raging. I wouldn't recommend any of these things, but it's your call.

The scientists are good folk, they are timid like rabbits. They wouldn't breathe into a flower directly, let along kill someone. I salute them, being here in such harsh conditions, while staying so dedicated to their cause. It's hard going on each day, knowing that your bunker could be overwhelmed by the scum of the Zone, and you couldn't do much. I'd rather have basic knowledge of gun handling, but these are educated people, people with a cause. I'm here because I need to sell artifacts. It helps with my terrible habit of collecting money. I've been doing that all of my life, spending as little as possible, and I still ended up here. I seem to be saving in all the wrong ways I guess. Develop some form of economy system. Buy optimal amounts of food, spend the least amount of ammo, just the right amount necessary for the job. Doing this, you'd have much better chances not ending up like me. But I'm a dreamer, a dreamer that collects money.

One thing I had to take from the outside. I know you aren't supposed to take anything here if you want to bring it back, because of all the radiation. But this was quite precious. It was a duckling. The cutest little yellow thing. Quacking like crazy all the time. I wanted to keep it inside, so it doesn't attract attention. I had a plan how to feed it and everything. It slept near my heart, where it was the warmest. I had it for 20 days, and when I came to the Zone, it didn't even survive a few hours. Normal animals don't last long here. Just those crows, and I'm not even sure they are normal at all. I've seen them scream like machines, and gouge eyes off of pseudogiants. They are vicious thieves too. If you have some trinkets, golden whatever, they will take it if stashed somewhere where they could reach it. One time a crow was shot out from the sky by this very very imprecise drunk shotgunner. It fell down, and it was holding this golden watch in it's beak. It reminded me of the duckling I had with me. I've seen my friends die painfully in the mud here, but thinking about that duckling just ravages my heart.

Nobody cares about us down here. It's like we don't even exist. The first few days we were in the spotlight. Stalkers, the Zone. Afterwards they started ignoring everything that comes out of this place. Mutants, artifacts, they all think it's some kind of a hoax. Sometimes I even wonder if these artifacts give off any beneficial effects. I mean how could we know? I know the scientists are working their magic back in the bunkers, but how do I know that a specific artifact is good for this, and not for another thing? It might just be old wives tales, superstitious people making stuff up, so they could feel safer in this wasteland. That's probably not an option since even a slight level of superstition here, gets you killed. I don't know, really, it's a bit too much for me. I know I believe in a loaded gun, and a sharp knife. That's my God right there, cocked and ready to go. I pray to that God by cleaning it and doing basic maintenance, and it's very rewarding. Especially when it doesn't get stuck and does exactly what it is made for.

I want to score big, just once. I've been here for a while now, why would I get lucky? I follow the right people, carry the right equipment, but it's always either a shitty Flesh, or if I'm extremely lucky, a boar. They are not profitable, to say the least. I spend 4 shots getting a boar down, and at most, I make 3 and a half shots back when I sell the stuff I take from it. Fleshes are not worth while, they barely sell well. You'd better chunk the meat and hunt for some bigger game. I heard that this one guy startled a pack of Snorks. He chucked a grenade at them while running away. He wasn't even looking back to see what happened, he just noticed that after the noise from the explosion died down, and the whistling in his ear lowered, he didn't hear the Snorks anymore. Now that's what I call scoring big. He took their feet and hands back to base, sold them at an excellent price. He went home with that money. Lucky bastard. If I waste a grenade at my boars, I would cut my own hand and sell it to the first trader that believes it's a Snork's hand.

Carrying a lot of equipment on you has it's toll. Exoskeletons are really cool, I know. But try running away from a pack of dogs with that thing. It will drain you like a leech. There was some talk about boosters that enable you to run, but you still drain fast. I would go for light armor if I was you. You have more options that way, and the best tactic here is actually not getting shot at all. No armor repairs, no pain, no medicine. It's safe and secure. Although it's a rarity for people to go on for a while managing this, it is quite rewarding when successful. You always have the choice to either pack armor attachments like Kevlar, or put some hydration upgrades that make life much easier.

Every time I see you around, I think to myself: "Now that is a guy who knows where he is going". I just loop around in circles, doing the exact same things each day. Getting bitten by Tushkano is not even exciting anymore. It's as if life has lost any meaning for me. It's bereft of any essence, and I feel I've done my share of living. It's easy getting lost here, ending up in an anomaly. Quick and painless. I've always wanted to end up with a death like that. My father was tortured before those bandits tore his throat out along with major arteries. I learned very quickly what happens to a person with torn arteries. That was my first sign that this is just a miserable game we are playing. Murdering our own kind is just too much for me. I couldn't even manage to retaliate, kill off a few bandits. I had names and whereabouts of each and every one of those bastards that did that to my father. But what is the point? We will all perish soon enough, I'd rather go immediately, than what my father went through.

Once I get my hands on a good sniper, I'm off to better places. I might even visit some zombie nests. With a sniper, I could fix each and every one of those Z's, without taking a single hit. But they don't come cheap, that bastard Owl sells it for a hand and a leg. I need my hand for sniping, and my legs are very important for running around as you might already be aware. Maybe that Haitian fella has some good deals. I never trust people that are all smiling and nice to me. There is always a catch behind those smiling mouths. I'm good with a sniper too, I used to train with the army. Not in the army, but with it, along with the army. It was an awkward situation, but I was better than some army grunts at sniping. Should've come here with more money, but it's hard to get anything outside, and harder inside. I do what I have to, and right now, I have to get me a sniper.

One more and I'm done. This is the last one I'm doing, and I've done a whole bunch. I used to bring in simple artifacts and pseudo artifacts. They weren't worth much, just enough to keep my belly filled with nasty shit that is edible. After I got my advanced detector, I got more expensive shit in. Beard knew my name, I was popular at Yanov. It isn't easy artifact hunting. You get burned, electrocuted and crushed. But it's gratifying. At least I don't have to put bullets in peoples heads for a living. Not a nice job that one. I had to do it once because some bandits tried to rob me while they were high as fuck on coke. All jittery and such, I had to put them down as fast as possible. Sold their coke too. I felt like a scumbag and a lowlife, but it had to be done. Now I know what routes the bandits have, and I try to not have face to face conversations with them. They don't seem to mind, or even notice me at all. I feel that is a perfect arrangement. But all that is in the past now, because this is my last run, and I'm going back to see my sweet sweet beasts. I have two Huskies, one is a big fucker, and the other has some coughing issues that I think science would never understand. Unless I pay them with artifacts. That would wake the veterinarians up I suppose.

Do you know what Perpetuum Mobile is? Of course you don't. I'm going to tell you now, and you better write this shit down. A scientist I used to know was researching the peculiar phenomena of lights being able to work after years being left without a power source, without maintenance, lift's too. It's like they were feeding on some source of energy, but it couldn't be determined what that was. They theorized that those objects had become stuck in the particular time when the Zone expanded. They didn't even seem to age at all. Naturally the military would want dibs on this technology, them and every company in the world. But these objects that could work seemingly indefinitely, just died when disconnected or taken outside the Zone. They were classified as proto-artifacts and for a while, they were deemed uninteresting to science. How aloof of them. Claiming anything in here uninteresting.

Independent scientist groups started popping up around the Zone lately. Folks that don't care for the strict regulations of the military, they even might be corporate scientists. Anyway, what they found was that the proto-artifact story was half right. What they found was that the Zone itself was saturated with magnetic fields of a very complex nature. Some electrical devices started charging themselves up without a plug, just by being in the Zone, and sometimes they overcharged, burning up in the process. Tesla worked on wireless energy transfer, or so they say. He would love to get his hands on any one of these artifacts. I bet Nikola Tesla would've been a good Stalker.

You know that this is hell on earth right? I mean you've been here more than a minute I presume? This shit is awful as it is, but it's even worse because it's like we are in the fucking stone age. Have you seen a functioning truck, hauling products? Have you seen a robot going into anomalies, fishing out artifacts while this quasi-Stalker pushes buttons from a safe distance? You haven't seen that, I know you haven't because I've never seen that myself. It just doesn't exist. Complex circuits fry up immediately here, and only smaller devices could be isolated from the harsh influence of the Zone. All the PDA's here have some form of magnetic shielding or barriers to resist the erosive magnetic forces. Simple mechanism fare much better here, but they too wear out much faster. Have you noticed how often you have to clean your shooter here? It's like any complex mechanism is a magnet for dust particles. Everything breaks down faster here, and the more complex it is, the quicker it becomes useless.

Every single device made to suck up the magnetic waves the Zone emits on a daily basis, fries up before anyone could do any solid measurements. You can't tame the Zone, you can't trick it into feeding you. Large scale engineering projects haven't been attempted because of that. It's like this place has it's own mind, and it does whatever it wants. And "it" certainly doesn't want to help us. If it did, it would make those controlers look like naked women. They would be far more efficient that way.

Have you tried contacting the outside from here? Mobile phones used to fry in peoples hands as they tried reaching someone outside. The Zone wants to keep it's secrets I guess. 3G, GPS, Radio waves, all get scrambled when directed from inside out, or the other way round. Even cables for fucks sake, they fry up too. It doesn't make any sense. Powerful military grade radios manage to maintain contact for only a few moments before they fry up. This place is a quiet desert, and it's bound to stay like that.

During the noosphere rupture a while ago, when the Zone became the Zone, something quite strange happened to some electrical circuitry. For reasons unknown to science, resistance of some circuits has been reduced to almost 1,5 µO·m which is a range normally only present in the most powerfull superconductors, those that are superchilled. This has made those circuits work parctically for years without any applied voltage as electrons are moving thru them in endless loops without lossing almost any energy. As a result, some circuits became self-sustaining, and perfectly preserved over the years, being able to propell whatever equipment was plugged into them at the moment of this massive emission. On the other hand, some circuits were completely blown out, and new circuits sometimes don't even work at all in here. This poses a problem for Scientists, especially since they have to magnetically seal their complex mechanisms, which takes a lot of effort, time and is quite costly. If this wasn't the case, I bet you'd be seeing a lot more scientists than Stalkers around the Zone.

What you never want to happen here, is to fall unconscious, or immobile. Then you are fucked. No Stalker, good guy or bad, would ever help you out, if you can't help yourself. Each time a bullet grazes you, or hits your barely bulletproof vest, that bitch hurts, like a motherfucker. Each painful, unpleasant or fucked up thing that happens to you, takes away from your will to continue moving. Your will to survive and resist the Zone's crushing power. A few more hits and you'd be struggling to stay conscious from the pain. Do not let that happen. That's when things end for you. There was this brand new wannabe Stalker, this newbie that just came out of the box, still shining with enthusiasm and energy, he thought if he invested in a good vest, some bullet proof plates, he'd be unstoppable. He died somewhere after he ate a few bullets with his chest plate. The pain was too much for him. He threw up his insides, and probably dehydrated right there. They found his flesh ripped apart by hungry doggies or something uglier. I don't want to tell the story of how they found your body, all right?

The human body is a very reliable machine. It can function flawlessly for decades, and it's one of the most complex systems in the known world. The Zone is a little bit different. Immune systems don't work as well, coughs last longer, cancer is obviously rampant. It's as if you are immediately drained once you step inside the Zone. To be able to work and function well inside, you need a very strong spirit, either in alcoholic form, or psychologically, preferably both. Some cowards won't stand one bite of those dogs, others can go through a pack of biting teeth and scratching claws. What is different is spirit, and sometimes drugs, but mostly spirit. You need to have strong and defined goals around here, to keep you going through the every day shit you see or survive. That is the difference between Newbies, Zone men and real Stalkers. Anyone can waltz in here, strutting shiny new weapons and cement armor, but when the going gets awful, some folk break much easier than others, and it doesn't have anything to do with the weapons you have, or the armor you are wearing. They do help, but what drives you inside, is what determines if you live or die.

We are a living through an experiment here. We are the fools that are completely fine getting electrocuted, poisoned, irradiated and cut, on a regular basis, just because a bit further down the road, there is this phantom waving an appealing artifact. It's obsessive compulsive man, Stalkers have died going for artifacts that are simply out of reach. Have you seen those bodies piled up in that fireball anomaly deep inside the crack in the earth? The artifacts are the fodder, and we are the lab rats, being studied by someone. Fuck that someone man. I'd cut his jugular artery if I knew who he was or maybe he's a she. All the better, I'd cut her too.

Many of my colleagues seem to forget that not every artifact is as fragile as glass. If you really have to get an artifact out of a spot that you cannot reach, use your pistol, assault rifle or whatever you have at hand, hell, even a grenade can work wonders.

Listen, you seem new and don't have a grasp on the rank structure here. I'm going to enlighten you, so pay attention. The grunts of the force are our privates and our sergeants. A sergeant enforces the policies and changes by those appointed over him and keeps the junior sergeants and privates in line. The senior privates follow through with these orders and teaches our new privates how to act. Senior sergeants and master sergeants are the brains of the operations, they've been here longer than the others and know their ways in and out. The officer structure here consists of junior lieutenants, lieutenants, senior lieutenants, and captains. Junior lieutenants are fresh out of the academy, they tend to know as much as privates and need to be looked after by their senior lieutenants. That being said, any officer is higher ranking than any enlisted member; the captains here may not have as much hands on experience as the master sergeants, but they make the calls around here.

I don't have a lot of information regarding the situation here. But remember, keep your eyes trained on everything at all times! Situational awareness, I'm sure they spouted that crap at you all during basic training. The situation here is real, we need to never lose focus of what's going on around us or else we could end up dead at any given moment. We're trapped in here with psychopaths, murders, killers, mercenaries, money-grubbers, and a fake military spin off to boot. Trust in your chain of command and always keep lines of communication between you and your superiors open. That's all I really have for information.

Contrary to popular belief between the privates, we really don't have a strong foothold here even around the cordon. These people just keep trying their luck in sneaking in and making a quick buck; they're all about the riches. If you ever find yourself in a bad situation and looking down the barrel of someone elses gun, entice them with a little cash incentive. The zone is a pretty harsh place, but with a little cash and a pretty trinket or two I believe it's like any other deployed location. We go through our 12 to 16 hour shift waiting for something to happen and when it doesn't we return to our bunk, watch some shitty porn and have a wank and then go straight to bed, piece of cake. I'm rambling, just don't get your head shot off and everything will be okay, nobody has time to fill out the paperwork for your death.

We used to keep our base of operations as a secret. Barely anyone except the long-dead Renegades knew about our existence and things were good, but things have changed horrifyingly after that big emission hit the Zone, like somewhen between one and two years ago... I can't really keep on track with the time... Before shit got real with that hard-ass mercenary, our base used to brim with life with Cold flinging dirty jokes at all directions and Grey fixing up even the most broken stuff, but where did they go now, I have no idea... I don't know about Cold, but rumors are that Grey found a job as a technician for the Ecologists' bunker in Yanov... it's all eerily quiet without them now, even if we opened up our base for guests outside of our faction, I mean... Librarian and the other new guys are alright, but I guess you know what I mean.

Clients have been playing us against each other. It's shitty business, but you do what you can to get the job done. If you see one of us on the other side, you do it quick, with respect. We'd do the same for you.

Watch out for the Ukrianians. There's a lot of conscripts doing their service around the Zone. They're jumpy, and trigger-happy to boot, so if you come across a patrol, just treat them like any other Tango. They'll have ammo and medical supplies, and we could use the rifle parts for any breaks or barrel modifications.

There was an emission earlier, so the chances are the anomalies have shifted a bit, and there might be a few artefacts to grab. That, and there'll be some poor souls turned into vegetables or zombies. Just pray you don't know them. The mutants will be going crazy too, so watch your step and keep your gun ready.
Remember to eat and drink. You can pray till you collapse, but we still need to defend the Wish Granter from heathens and non-believers.
